title: January 12
description: We had all manner of exciting kid events and sleepovers this weekend, but they will be forever lost to posterity because Dean took the camera on a solo trip to Pinnacles National Park.

children.title: Pinnacles
children.description:
Pinnacles National Park is the nation's newest: it became a national park January 10, 2013.

Dean went for its one year birthday. There wasn't much of a party: besides some diehard rock climbers, he pretty much had the joint to himself.

children.title: Spires
children.description: The rock spires and other weird formations are the eroded leftovers of the western half of an extinct volcano.   It's moved 150 miles from its original location on the San Andreas Fault.

children.title: Caves
children.description:
It has a bunch of talus caves, meaning they were formed by giant boulders dropping into narrow gorges.

You need a flashlight to hike the paths through the caves. Thirteen species of bats live in them. At least half of those species were intent on buzz-diving Dean on a night hike.

children.title: Arch
children.description:
The California condor, which became extinct in the wild in 1987, is being reintroduced here from birds bred in captivity.

There's 13 condors in the park. Dean saw at least a handful, and talked to a biologist at the top of a mountain who had a big tracking antenna.

children.title: Hiking
children.description: Pinnacles has great mountain hikes.  We'll be back with the whole family!
